awd_titl_txt: Exploring the Potential of Tablets as Early Math Resources for Urban Kindergarteners in Schools and Homes
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine the impact on mathematics learning of an initiative to provide kindergartners in an urban school district with personal tablet devices that include free, widely available digital mathematics resources. An important question for schools as tablet devices become more accessible is how to effectively use them in primary grades, especially kindergarten. In addition, since the devices are portable, how children use the resources such as games for mathematics learning at home is also important to understand. This project is set in a high-needs school district with a large number of low-income children. The project provides an opportunity to learn about the potential role of tables and digital resources in early grades through the analysis of assessment data, user analytic data documenting how the resources were used, and survey data from teachers and families. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Most studies of digital learning resources have been small-scale or focused on engagement. This study offers the opportunity to investigate the relationship between the use of these resources and learning outcomes using a quasi-experimental design. The research questions examine how teachers use table-based mathematics resources during instruction, how caregivers and children engage with table-based mathematics resources and how the resources then relate to kindergartners mathematics learning. Assessments of students' learning will focus on number, geometry and measurement concepts. The learner analytic data from the tablets will document the use of the resources on the tablets. Surveys and demographic data will also be collected to document how the tablets were used. Results of the study should inform implementation of tablet use by schools with particular attention to how they are used across in-class and at-home settings.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this study was to examine the impact of a technology donation effort undertaken through a partnership among a university, a local public television station, and a small urban school district. The television station and the university donated enough tablets to the school district to supply every kindergartener with a device for their personal use in school. At the end of the year tablets were sent home with the children. The school district and the public television station did not budget for or plan professional development efforts to go along with the tablet-infusion, although check-ins where teachers could ask questions were held during monthly instructional meetings.

For this study, we were particularly interested in documenting the perceptions of the donation effort by multiple stakeholders as well as any impacts on children’s learning in mathematics. The focus on mathematics was chosen for pragmatic reasons because the tablet’s designers loaded the device with mathematics applications that allowed usage data of these games to be tracked remotely using the school’s internet connection. 

The study used a mixed methods design to capture stakeholder perspectives on the tablets program as well as children’s achievement in mathematics and literacy. The design was a cluster-randomized controlled trial. Kindergarten classes were randomly assigned within schools to treatment or control conditions. Treatment classes received classroom sets of tablets with the suite of PBS mathematics games installed and instructions to use the games 2-3 times a week for 10-15 minutes at a time. Control classrooms received classroom sets of tablets that they could use as they saw fit, but these devices were not equipped with the suite of PBS math games. 

The district administered the AIMSweb Tests of Early Numeracy and Early Literacy in Fall 2017 and Spring 2018. The Test of Early Numeracy included four subtests that targeted foundational mathematics skills: Oral Counting, Number Identification, Quantity Discrimination, and Missing Number Identification. The Test of Early Literacy included two subtests that were administered at both time points: Letter Naming and Letter Sounds. Each tablet assigned to a student in the treatment group was given a unique ID number and data on the use of the PBS math games was tracked remotely.  Usage was measured in terms of the total amount of time the child spent playing the games in minutes between the distribution of the tablets (end of 2017) and the end of the school year (June 2018).

The goal of the qualitative side of the study was to use surveys and interviews to understand the perceptions (both positive and negative) of the tablets project from a variety of perspectives, including administrators, teachers, and family members.

Overall, this study found that while teachers enjoyed the tablets and reported using them frequently and outside partners in the project appreciated the opportunities for collaboration, research and marketing, engagement with the mathematics games did not lead to greater achievement in tested math skills. There are several possible explanations for this lack of effect, several of which may be operating in tandem. Most importantly, the games were not frequently used by most of the students in the study, averaging on 13 minutes per week across all the games. Previous studies which have demonstrated positive effects of digital applications on math learning had children use the digital applications more than twice as much (30 minutes per week). The fact that high volume users did demonstrate effects on one subtest may indicate that the games could have a beneficial effect. Relatedly, the quality of the games may not have supported either skill growth or sustained use.  The games were not adaptive and did not provide students with ways to demonstrate mastery or move up through levels. Thus, the games may have quickly become too easy or boring for many children.  In addition, the use of the games was not integrated into instruction or assigned to particular children based on their needs. Instead, children were often allowed to operate the tablets independently and “find their learning” which may explain while even children who could have benefitted from extended practice on basic mathematical skills did not demonstrate increased learning. 

This study, as with previous research, suggests that although teachers and children enjoy using technology, frequent use of digital resources – even those that explicitly focus on particular academic skills, such as oral counting or one-to-one correspondence, does not necessarily lead to greater academic achievement on its own. In addition, the study shows that positive feelings about infusion of technology in the broader eco-system around a classroom’s technology intervention do not necessarily lead to opportunities for learning. In particular, donations of technology may provide joy about “giving back” for donors without necessarily impacting learning, and administrators with the power to fund and design technology initiatives may do so for reasons other than meaningful impact on student learning.
